author: Victoria Monk
title: Thorpe Park: everything you need to know about visiting this summer
text: Situated near Chertsey, 20 miles from London, Thorpe Park is not for the faint‑hearted. It has some of the biggest roller coasters in Europe and the rides here are built to scare. It is perfect for adrenalin junkies and thrill seekers, but there are limited alternatives for small children. What’s new Island Beats is Thorpe Park’s new music event, running until August 29, when ride time is extended to 10pm each Friday and Saturday and a headline act will perform at the Lost City Stage: confirmed artists for August include Union J and Conor Maynard (prices from £25). • The ultimate guide to the UK's theme parks The family-friendly I’m a Celebrity Get me Out of Here! maze opened this year, encompassing jungle tests such as a vibrating bridge, water jets and multi-sensory leg ticklers that simulate crawling insects; best for ages eight and up. Thumbs up Nothing quite compares to the rush you feel when hurtled from 0-80mph in under two seconds on Stealth’s 65.5m vertical face – it becomes a bit addictive after the first go. If you’re feeling particularly brave, The Swarm – Britain’s first winged roller coaster – is slightly less terrifying, but still has an ominous apocalyptic feel, and the bonus (or otherwise) of riding backwards. A point of view video of Stealth at Thorpe Park The Shark Hotel , which opened last year, is convenient, affordable and gives early morning access to the rides. “Bite-sized” rooms, with free Wi-Fi cost from £39.99 pppn, which includes two-day resort ticket, parking, and breakfast. As a break from the coasters, and with lower height restrictions, there are five decent water rides (min 0.9m/3ft, under 1.2m/4ft accompanied by an adult); Tidal Wave is the toughest and will soak you – cooling on a hot day, otherwise rather chilly. Amity Beach with water slides and paddling pool, is a good option for young children. • The 10 best family days out from London Thumbs down Queues can be exceptionally long; unless you want to spend most of your day in one, budget for a Fastrack – (£8 for four water rides; £11 for Colossus, Nemesis Inferno, X and either Tidal Wave or Logger’s Leap), though even then you’ll have significant waits. While there are plenty of food outlets, quality is poor – expect burgers and undercooked French fries. • 50 great days out in the UK Top tips Head to the most popular rides first to beat the midday madness. If you haven’t got time to do them all, skip Nemesis Inferno – it’s the least memorable. You must be 1.4m (4ft 7in) tall to go on the signature rides Store the bulk of your possessions in the on-site lockers, freeing you to run for an extra go on your favourite rides Prices Online, one-day tickets cost from £29.99, all ages (0871 663 1673; thorpepark.com ). Opening times vary, 10am to 7pm in August. Telegraphtravel Follow @telegraphtravel
